Ayssi comensan las paraulas de Albucasim .	Thus begin the words of Albucasis. 
O, filhs, pus yeu he a vos complit aquest libre, le qual es le derier de la sciencia de medicina, per le compliment de lu so consequit la fi en lu, e per las exposicios de lu, e per las declaracios de lu, es a mi vist que yeu complesca aquel a vos am aquest tractat, le qual es partida de la operacio am ma, so es cyrurgia.	O, son, since I have completed for you this book, which is the last on the science of medicine, by its completion its purpose is achieved, and through its expositions and declarations, it seems to me appropriate that I complete it for you with this treatise, which is part of the practice with the hand, that is surgery.
Quar la operacio am ma es prostrada en nostre regio e en nostre temps de tot privada, entro que fort leu peric la sciencia de lu, e le vistigi de lu es ostat; e no romasero de lu sino alcunas petitas descripcios en les libres dels Antics, les quals mudero las mas e endevenc ad aquels error e heyssitacio entro que son clausas las entencios de lu e es elonguada la forsa de lu e l’art.	For the practice with the hand [surgery] is neglected in our region and in our time completely abandoned, so that its knowledge will soon be lost, and its vestige removed; and nothing will remain of it but a few small descriptions in the books of the Ancients, which will mislead the hands and lead those [who practice it] into error and hesitation, so that its meanings are obscured and its strength and art diminished.
E es vist a mi que yeu vivifique aquela am ordenacio de aquest tractat en aquela segon la via de exposicio e de declaracio e de abreviacio; e per que vengua am las formas dels ferramentz de cautheri e dels autres instrumentz de la obra cum sia per addicio de la declaracio, e per preparacio de lu, la qual causa es necessaria.	And it seems to me appropriate that I revive it [surgery] with the organization of this treatise, according to the way of exposition and declaration and abbreviation; and that it comes with the forms of cautery instruments and other instruments of the work, as well as the addition of the explanation, and its preparation, which is necessary.
Mays la causa per la qual no es atrobat bo artifex am la sieua ma en aquest nostre temps, es quar la art de medicina es longua, e que cove le sieu actor denant aquo esser excercitat en la sciencia de anotomia la qual recontec Gualia entro que sapia les juvament dels membres e las formas de aquels, e la conjunctio e la separacio de lor; e haia la conoyssensa dels osses, dels nervis e dels lacertz, e·l nombre de aquels, e la egrecio de lor; e de las venas pulsatils e de las quietas, e dels locs del eyssiment de lor.	But the reason why no good craftsman with his hand [skilled surgeon] is found in our time is because the art of medicine is long, and its practitioner must first be trained in the science of anatomy, which includes knowing the positions of the limbs and their shapes, and their connection and separation from each other; and have knowledge of the bones, nerves, and muscles, and their number, and their origin; and of the pulsating and quiet veins, and the locations of their exits.
E per aquo ditz Ypocras que am u nom es mot, mays en l’obra petit, e majorment en la art de la ma.	And for this reason Hippocrates said that with one name there is much [said], but in practice little, and especially in the art of the hand [surgery].
Mays nos ja avem dit de aquel en l’introit de aquest libre; quar qui no es scient aquo que li avem dit de anotomia, no es evacuat que no caia en error per la qual siran mortz les homes, ayssi cum yeu he vist trops de aquels, quar alscus son formatz en esta sciencia e gettan se de aquela ses sciencia e ses experiment.	But we have already spoken of this in the introduction to this book; for whoever is not knowledgeable in what we have said about anatomy, it is unavoidable that they will fall into error, by which men will die, just as I have seen many of them, because some are instructed in this science and throw themselves into it without knowledge and without experience.
Quar yeu vi un metge folh e enperit aver incidit un apostema escrophilos en le colh de una femna, e incidic alcunas arterias del colh per que fluic gran sanc entro que la femna cazec morta entre las mas de lu.	For I saw a foolish and ignorant physician incise a scrofulous abscess on the neck of a woman, and cut some arteries of the neck so that much blood flowed until the woman fell dead in his hands.
E vi un autre metge que pres que el traguera una peyra d’un home le qual avia procesit en sa etat, e la peyra era gran, e venguet a lu e trayssec aquela peyra am un tros de la vesiqua, per que aquel home al tertz dia es mort.	And I saw another physician who intended to extract a stone from a man which had developed in his age, and the stone was large, and he came to him and pulled out that stone with a piece of the bladder, so that the man died on the third day.
E yeu ja apelat fuy a estrayre aquela, e vi que per la grandesa de la peyra e per la disposicio del malaute conogui subre lu que morira.	And I was called to extract it, and I saw that because of the size of the stone and the condition of the patient, I realized that he would die.
E vi un autre metge le qual prenia stipendic de un duc de nostra terra per cyrurgia, e endeven a un crastrat negre le qual era deves lu fractura en la coyssa de lu; e perparec le metge am la sua ignorancia, estrayssec la fractura, sobre la plagua, am pulvinas e astelas am forta strectura, e no layssec a la plagua espiracio.	And I saw another physician who received a stipend from a duke of our land for surgery, and it happened to a black eunuch who had a fracture in his thigh; and the physician, in his ignorance, prepared the fracture, on the wound, with cushions and splints with strong tightening, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
E aprop le desliet segons los sieus desiriers, e aprop le relieg, e aprop le leyssec per alcus jorns e comandec que nos deslies le liament; e estec ayssi entro que la coyssa e·l pe foro apostematz, e pervenguet a perdicio.	And then he untied it according to his wishes, and then he re-bandaged it, and then he left it for some days and ordered us to untie the bandage; and it remained thus until the thigh and foot were abscessed, and it resulted in ruin/loss (of the limb).
E yeu fuy apelat a lu, e aparelhegui a desliar le liament, e conseguida es tranquilitat e enayssi amermet de sas dolors.	And I was called to him, and I prepared to loosen the bandage, and tranquility was achieved, and thus his pains lessened. 
Mays empero ja corrupcio era confermada en le membre, per que no pogui refrenar aquela, e no cessec perambular la corrupcio en le membre entro que·l malaute peric.	But however, corruption was already established in the limb, so I could not restrain it, and the corruption in the limb did not cease spreading until the patient perished/died.
E vi un autre metge le qual perforec un apostema cancros, e fo ulcerat aprop alscus dias, entro que foc magnificada la malicia de lu am lo senhor de lu.	And I saw another physician who lanced a cancerous abscess, and it ulcerated for some days, until its malignancy was magnified with its host/patient.
La qual causa es quar le cranc caut es pur de humor melencolic, lahoras no cove que pervengua a lu am ferr de tot, sino que sia an membre le qual suffertes que de tot fos hostat.	The reason for this is that since cancer is caused by pure melancholic humor, it is not appropriate that it be touched with an iron instrument at all, unless it is in a limb that can be entirely removed. 
E per aquo, filhs, necessari es a vos que la operacio am ma sia devisada en dos devesios: so es en operacio a lu qual es associada salut, e en obra am la qual es perilh en las majors disposicios.	And therefore, my son, it is necessary for you that the operation with my hand be divided into two parts: that is, into an operation with which health is associated, and into a work with which there is danger in the most serious cases.
E yeu ja he exsitat aquo en tot loc de aquest libre en le qual venc opperacio en la qual es error e temor; per que necessari es a vos que guardetz aquo e layssetz aquel, per que les folhs no atrobo via a parlar e a vos desonestar.	And I have already explained this in every place in this book where there is an operation in which there is error and fear; therefore it is necessary for you to heed this and abandon that, so that fools do not find a way to criticize and dishonor you. 
E donc prenetz las vostras armas am sollicitut e am proteccio de Dieu , e les vostres malautes am falicitat e am fermetat.	And so take up your work with care and with God's protection, and [treat] your patients with success and with confidence. 
E usatz de la milhor via per la gracia de Dieu perdusent a salut e a lausabla successio, e laysatz las malautias terriblas de difficil sanacio, e ostatz las vostras armas de aquo que vos fa temer, per so que ysitatio en vostra fe e en le vostre nom no vos evasisca: quar mays es remanent a la vostra gloria, e pus aut en le mon e en derier a las vostras sanctitatz.	And proceed in the best way, by the grace of God leading to health and laudable success, and leave aside the terrible diseases of difficult healing, and withdraw your efforts from that which makes you afraid, so that hesitation in your faith and in your reputation does not escape you: for more will remain to your glory, and later on high in the world and behind, to your holiness.
Gualia ja diyssec en alcunas sieuas monicios:	As Gualia already said in some of his admonitions:
“No mediquetz malautia mala, per so que mals metges no siatz nompnatz”.	Do not treat a bad/severe disease, so that you are not called a bad doctor.
E yeu ja he devesit aquest libre segontz tres capitols.	And I have already divided this book according to three chapters.
Comensa la divisio del libre, e primier de la primieyra partida.	Here begins the division of the book, and first of the first part.
Le primier capitol ordenat del cap entro·s pes, en las formas dels instrumentz e en les ferrementz dels cauteris, e de aquo que necessari es en la opperacio.	The first chapter discusses (is arranged/ordered) from the head to the feet, the shapes of the instruments and the cautery irons, and what is necessary for the operation.
La divisio de la segonda partida.	The division of the second part.
Le segon capitol, de siccio e perforacio, e de ventosas, e de plaguas, e de extractio de sagetas e de semblantz ad aquelas, tot capitolat e ordenat de las formas dels instrumentz.	The second chapter, on drying and perforation, cupping, wounds, and extraction of arrows and similar things, all categorized and ordered by the forms of the instruments.
Divisio de la tersa partida.	Division of the third part.
Le tertz capitol, de restauracio e de dislocacio, e de curacio de torcio e de semblantz ad aquels; capitol ordenat del cap entro·s pes, e de las formas dels instrumentz.	The third chapter, on restoration and dislocation, and the treatment of sprains and similar things; a chapter arranged from the head to the feet, and on the forms of the instruments.
De cauteri am foc e am medicina aguda e rememoracio de la opperacio.	On cauterization with fire and with corrosive medicine and a reminder of the operation/procedure.
Am aquel comensa le tractat de tot le libre.	With this begins the treatise of the whole book.
Cove que yeu digua la qualitat dels juvamentz de aquel cauteri e dels noccumentz de lu, e en qual compleccio sia prohibit cauteri.	It is fitting that I describe the qualities of the benefits of this cautery and its harms, and in which complexion cautery is prohibited.
Donc dic que·l sermo de la qualitat del juvament de cauteri e del noccument de lu es sermo lonc e prolixs, e subtil per sciensa, e secret amaguat; e ja de lu a parlat gran multitut de savis, e de lu se son desacordatz, et a mi abasta un petit dels sermons de lor, temen perlonguacio.	Therefore, I say that the discussion of the quality of the benefit of cautery and its harm is a long and lengthy discussion, and subtle in terms of knowledge, and a hidden secret; and a great multitude of wise men have already spoken about it, and they have disagreed about it, and a little of their discussions is enough for me, fearing lengthiness.
E donc dic que cauteri comfereys a tota compleccio universalment la qual es am materia o ses materia, exceptat dos compleccios, las quals son compleccios caudas ses materia .	And so I say that you may perform cautery on every complexion universally, whether it has matter or not, except for two complexions, which are hot complexions without matter. 
En la compleccio cauda e secca am materia se desecordero; quar alcus dyssero que cauteri es juvatiu ad aquela, e les autres dyssero le contrari de aquel, que cauteri no es convenient en malautia la qual es per qualiditat e per siccitat, quar natura del foc es qualiditat e siccitat, e enconvenient es que malautia cauda e secca am aquo que es caut e sec sia sanada.	Regarding the hot and dry complexion with matter, they disagreed; for some said that cautery is beneficial to it, and others said the contrary, that cautery is not suitable in an illness which is characterized by heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat and dryness, and it is unsuitable that a hot and dry illness be healed with something that is hot and dry.
E diysec aquel que ditz le contrari de aquel, que per cauteri es fayt juvament en tota malautia cauda e secca que ve en les cors dels homes, quar quan tu comparas le cors de home e las humiditatz de lu a la compleccio del foc, atrobas le cors de home freg.	And whoever says the opposite of this claims that cautery is beneficial in every hot and dry illness that occurs in the bodies of men, because when you compare the body of a man and his humors to the complexion of fire, you find the body of a man cold.
E yeu dic per le sermo de aquel, que esperiment aquo ja a mi alscunas vetz a descubert.	And I say, regarding his statement, that experience has already revealed this to me several times.
Mays empero no cove que vengua sobre aquo aquel que ja es exproat e excersitat en le capitol de cauteri per derier exercici, e a conogut la diversitat de la compleccio dels homes e la disposicio de las malautias en lor meteyssas, e las causas de aquelas, e·ls accidentz de lor, e l’espasi del temps de aquelas.	But still, it is not appropriate for someone to attempt this who has not already been tested and practiced in the chapter on cautery by past practice, and who has not learned about the diversity of men's complexions and the disposition of diseases in themselves, and their causes, and their accompanying symptoms, and the duration of their time. 
Mays en las autras compleccios, no es sobre vos temor, e majorment en las malautias fregas e humidas, quar ja totz les metges se son acordatz sobre aquels, e no so desecordatz en le juvament am cauteri en aquelas.	But in other complexions, there is no fear for you, and especially in cold and humid illnesses, for all doctors agree on these, and they are not in disagreement on the benefits of cautery in those cases.
E sapiatz, filhs, que del secret de curacio per cauteri am foc e de la bontat de lu, so sobre cauteri am medicina comburent, es quar le foc es simple, la accio del qual no perven sino al membre le qual es cauterizat e no notz al autre membre am lu ajustat sino am petit nocument.	And know, sons, that the secret of healing by cautery with fire, and its advantage over cautery with burning medicine, is because fire is simple, the action of which only reaches the part that is cauterized and does not harm the other parts connected to it, except with little harm/side effects.
Mays la accio de medicina comburent perven ad aquel en les membres le qual de lu alunhat, e fort leu fa venir en le membre malautia de dificil sanacio e fort leu ausit.	But the action of burning medicine reaches the other parts distant from it, and very easily brings about an illness in the body that is difficult to heal and occurs very quickly.
Mays le foc, per la sua sublimitat e de la sua substancia bontat, no fa aquo sino que superfluisca E ja es a nos conogut per experiment e per longitut de servitut de studi am l’art sobre le veritat de las causas; e per aquo yeu so excusat de la longitut del sermo E si no fos que no es legut al mieu libre en aquest pausero a vos secret amaguat am le foc, e la qualitat de la operacio de lu en les cors e de la sieua expulcio per la qual expellis las malautias, am sermo philosophic demostratiu, le qual siria acuit en las vostras pessas.	But fire, due to its sublime nature and the goodness of its substance, does not do this, but only removes excess.  And it is already known to us through experiment and lengthy service of study in the art concerning the truth of these matters; and therefore I am excused for the length of this discussion. And if it were not forbidden for me to include in this book a secret hidden from you about fire, and the nature of its operation within bodies and its expulsion by which it expels illnesses, with philosophical demonstration, which would be burdensome to your minds...
E sapiatz, filhs, que els se desacordan del temps en le qual es convenient far cauteri e pausan le milhor temps de primaveyra.	And know, sons, that they (doctors/people) disagree about the time in which it is appropriate to perform cautery and suggest the best time is spring.
E yeu dic que cauteri es convenient en tot temps, per so que le nocument per le temps accident es submergit en le juvament de aquo que am le cauteri es atirat, e majorment si le cauteri es per dolors o de dolors necessaries, fortz e fistinas, las quals no suffertan tarditat per so que es temut de aquelas que vengua malicia, que es major que petit nocument entrant per lo temps.	And I say that cautery is appropriate at all times, because the harm caused by the timing of it is outweighed by the benefit that is obtained with the cautery, and especially if the cautery is for pains or necessary pains, strong and sudden, which do not allow delay because it is feared that from them will come a worse problem, which is greater than the small harm introduced by the timing.
E aysso no catz en vostras pessas, o, filhs, aquo no estiman sino le poble vulguar e les fols metges, so es que ad aquela malautia que es sanada per cauteri no es redicio tot temps, e pausan aquel consequen.	And do not hold in your minds, oh sons, this thing that only the common people and foolish doctors believe, which is that there is not always a recurrence of the illness that is healed by cautery, and they posit this as a consequence.
E la causa no es ges ayssi quo els cuydan per aquo, quar cauteri no es sino en loc de medicina la qual altera la compleccio e esicca las humiditatz las quals son causa per que veno las dolors.	And the reason is not at all as they think it is, for cautery is nothing but a medicine which alters the constitution and dries the humors which are the cause from which the pains come.
Mays empero cauteri superflueys sobre la medicina per volicitat de la sua valitut e vertut de la sua operacio e grandesa del sieu senhor.	But nevertheless, cautery surpasses medicine by the speed of its effectiveness and the power of its action and the greatness of its master (God/physician).
E es possible que la sua malautia retorne en alcuna hora del temps, segon la compleccio del malaute e la locacio de la sua malautia, e la vertut de lu, e aquo que es preparat en le cors de lu de la agreguacio de las superfluitatz en lu, e aquo que es pervengut a lu en la sua acquisicio en viandas e semblantz de aquelas causas; sino que la malautia en la qual sia aministrat cauteri sia malautia subtil en membre de paucas superfluitatz e humiditatz, ayssi cum cauteri de dent per dolor e semblantz ad aquel, possible es que en lu no retorne aquela dolor, mays aquo se fa en petitz.	And it is possible that their illness will return at some point in time, depending on the patient's constitution and the location of their illness, and their strength, and what is prepared in their body from the aggregation of superfluities within them, and what has happened to them in their acquisition of food and similar such causes; but if the illness in which cautery is administered is a subtle illness in a part with few superfluities and humors, such as cautery of a tooth for pain and similar things, it is possible that the pain will not return to them, but this happens in only a few cases.
E mays sermo vulgar es que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, e es sermo dreyturier, no ad aquo que els entendo en lu, quar els crezo que no es curacio que aprofieyta am medicina ni am autra causa aprop cauteri.	And it is common talk that cautery is the last remedy of medicine, and it is a true statement, but not in the way they understand it, for they believe that there is no cure that benefits with medicine or any other thing after cautery.
E la causa es en contrari de aquo; e la entencio que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina no es sino quan administram las manieyras de curacio en alcunas malautias, e aquelas medicinas no conferieysso, e aprop en la fi de la causa aministra hom cauteri, e aprofieyta ad aquela.	And the reason is contrary to this; and the understanding that cauteri is the last remedy of medicine is only when we administer the methods of treatment in some diseases, and those medicines are not effective, and then at the end of the matter one administers cautery, and it benefits the condition.
E lahoras de aqui cat16 que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, no segon la entencio la qual entendo les vulgars e trops dels fols metges.	And from this it appears that cautery is the last remedy of medicine, not according to the understanding which the common people and many foolish doctors have.
E diyssero les antics que cauteri am aur es milhor que cauteri am ferr, e no diyssero aquo sino per la equalitat del aur e sublimitat de la sua sustancia.	And the ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron, and they said this only because of the evenness of gold and the sublimity/purity of its substance.
E diyssero que le loc de cauteri no fa brac, cum aquo no sia absolutament vertat, quar yeu ja he aquo proat e he atrobat que aquel no fa aquo sino en alcus cors ses les autres, e cauteri am aquel es bo e milhor que am ferr ayssi quo els diyssero; mays empero quan tu fas cauteri am foc am de aur, no es a tu declarat, quar es egnit segon la quantitat que tu vols per la rugor de l’aur, e quar prepara a recebre freg; e si ajustas sobre lu ignicio se fon l’aur per le foc, e caso en le foc alcunas laminas per que le artifex catz per la occupacio de aquel.	And they said that the place of cautery does not develop an ulcer/inflammation, which is not entirely true, for I have already tested this and have found that it does not do this except in some bodies but not others, and cautery with it (gold) is good and better than with iron, just as they said; but however when you cauterize with fire with gold, it is not clear to you, for it is born/created according to the amount that you want by the redness of the gold, and because it prepares to receive cold; and if you add ignition onto it, the gold melts by the fire, and some flakes fall into the fire, by which the artisan sees through the work/occupation of that.
E per aquo es fayt cauteri am ferr deves nos pus leugerament e pus propdanament a rectitut de operacio.	And therefore cautery is done with iron by us more easily and more appropriately to the correctness of the operation.
E yeu ja he ordenat aquest capitol en le cauteri segon capitols, et he ordenat aquels del cap entro les pes, per so que aleugo le demandant aquo que vol de lu.	And I have already arranged this chapter on cautery according to chapters, and I have arranged them from the head to the feet, so that the inquirer may find there what he wants.
De cauteri de dolor de cap per frigiditat e humiditat.	On cautery for head pain due to coldness and humidity/wetness.
Le capitol primier.	The first chapter.
Aquesta cauterizacio confereys a la humiditat e frigiditat sobre le servel accident de la qual so doas causas, so es causa de soda e multitut de flux raumatic, apelat corissa, del cap a las partidas dels huelhs e de las aurelhas fluent, e multitut de dormir, e de dolor de dentz e del guolayro, e universalment de tota malautia que ve per fregiditat, ayssi cum paraliticament, sodo e apoplexio, e semblantz en aquelas malautias.	This cauterization is applied for coldness and wetness/humidity affecting the brain, from which arise two things:  a runny nose, called coryza, flowing from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and excessive sleep, toothache, and throat pain, and generally every illness that comes from coldness, such as paralysis, lethargy and apoplexy, and similar ailments.
La forma de aquesta cauterizacio es aquesta, que primieyrament comandes al malaute que sia evacuat am medicina lacsativa le cap mondificant, per tres o per quatre nueytz, segon que exhigeys la vertut del malaute e la edat de lu e la sua costuma.	The method of this cauterization is as follows: first, order the patient to be purged with a laxative medicine that cleanses the head, for three or four nights, according to the strength of the patient and their age and habit.
E aprop comanda li que raza le sieu cap am razor, e aprop fay aquel sezer entre las tuas mas sobre una banca cayrada e que pause las suas mas sobre le pietz sieu.	And then order him to shave his head with a razor, and then have him sit between your hands on a square bench and place his hands on his feet.
E aprop pausa la razit de la tua palma aprop le pous sobre la razit del nas entre les huels sieus.	And then place the root of your palm near the thumb upon the bridge of his nose, between his eyes.
Mays empero, cum le tieu dit del mieg loc es pervengut, signa aquel loc am tenta, e aprop igneys le cauteri olivar del qual aquesta es la forma:	But, however, when your middle finger has reached [a certain spot], mark that place with ink, and then burn it with an olive-shaped cautery, of which this is the form:
E aprop pausa aquel sobre le loc senhat am tenta, a manieyra que descent, am la qual la tieua ma sia constrengida petit a petit, e tu revolveys aquel.	And then place it upon the spot marked with ink, in such a way that it descends, with which your hand should be constricted little by little, and you should turn it.
E aprop leva la tua ma leugerament e reguarda le loc, e si veses ja del os esser descubert alcuna quantitat del cap, ayssi cum la quantitat de gra de errs, lahoras eleva la tua ma, e si no torno la tua ma am aquel ferr, am autre de aquel, si es enfrigidat, entro que sia vist del os aquo que yeu he dit a tu.	And then lift your hand lightly and examine the place, and if you see that some amount of the skull bone, about the size of a chickpea, has been exposed, then raise your hand; and if not, return your hand with that iron, or with another one if it has cooled, until you see as much bone exposed as I have told you.
E aprop pren un petit de sal e disolveys aquel sobre le loc e leyssa aquel per tres jorns.	And then take a little salt and dissolve it on the spot and leave it for three days.
E aprop pausa sobre lu coto enbegut en boder e leyssa aquel sobre lu entro que sia destrusida la scara del foc.	And then place upon it cotton soaked in pus/discharge and leave it there until the burn scab is destroyed/falls off.
E aprop cura le loc am anguent tetrafarmacon entro que sia sanat.	And then treat the area with tetrapharmacon ointment until it is healed.
E ja diyssero que quant la plagua roman uberta, tant mielhs geta le brac, per que es milhor e mays juvatiu.	And they already said that when the wound remains open, the pus/discharge drains better, because it is better and more helpful/beneficial.
E diyssero alcus de lor que sia cauterizada la codena entro al os, e sia tengut le cauteri entro que sia adhurida alcuna partida de la specitut del os.	And some of them said that the nape of the neck should be cauterized down to the bone, and the cautery should be held there until some part of the surface of the bone is burned.
E aprop sia ras aquo que es adhust del os, e aprop sia curat.	And then what is burned of the bone should be scraped, and then it should be treated/dressed.
E diyssero autres que am lo cauteri pervengua al derier, entro que enprema en le os forta enprecio entro que le os caga, e aquesta es la forma de alphecati petit:	And others said that with the cautery one should reach the back, until it presses strongly on the bone until the bone decays/breaks down, and this is the form of a small incision/cauterization:
E estiman de aquel loc expiran la vapors del cap.	And they believe that the vapors of the head escape from that place. 
E sia tenguda la plagua uberta per lonc temps, e aprop sia curada entro que sia consolidada.	And the wound should be kept open for a long time, and then treated/dressed until it is healed/closed.
Mays a mi no so vistas aquestas doas specias de cauteri de tot, sino en alcus homes segon via de temor; e layssa aquel, deves mi, milhor es am salut, quan es; quar le cap es develitat per solucio de continuitat de lu ayssi cum havem testificat en les autres membres, e majorment quan le cap del malaute es de freul natura.	But these two types of cautery have not been seen by me at all, except in some men by way of fear/as a frightening method; and leaving that (method), believe me, it is better with health, when it exists; for the head is weakened by the breaking of its continuity in this way as we have testified in other limbs, and even more so when the patient's head is of a cold nature. 
E la specia de cauteri primieyra es mays salva e milhor deves mi; e de aquela husi e am aquela obra am salut.	And the first type of cautery is safer and better in my opinion; and I use that one and with that one I work with/for health.
Capitol segon.	Chapter Two.
Del cauteri del cap.	Of cauterization of the head. /  Concerning cauterization of the head.
Quan en tot le cap accideys dolor cronica e longua e aquo es en le malaute prolonguat, e usa de gerras e de cochias e de capipurges e de emplaustres e de guatz e de cadels e de gualinas e de semblantz, e majorment si ja es cauterizat am un cautere le qual recontam e no aprofieyta a lu deguna de aquelas causas, lahoras considera quar si le cap del malaute es de fort creacio en la sua natura; e no es freul et atroba mot gran freg, lahoras aquel cauterisa am autra cauteri dejos aquel un pauc.	When chronic and prolonged pain occurs in the whole head and this is protracted in the patient, and (he) uses leeches and cupping glasses and head purges and plasters and poultices and puppies and chickens and similar things, and especially if he has already been cauterized with a cautery which we describe and none of those things benefits him, then consider whether the patient's head is of a strong constitution in its nature; and it is not cold, and finds much great cold, then cauterize that (head) with another cautery a little below the first one.
E aprop cauterisa aquel sobre le corn del sieu cap am cauteri entro que la codena es partida.	And then cauterize that (area) above the crown of his head with a cautery until the skin is broken/split.
Incisa la codena e sia descuberta del os la quantitat la qual havem recontat e cauteriza aquel am un cauteri en la partida deriera del cap en le loc le qual es apelat vas, — e es aquel loc en le qual es pausada ventosa.	Incise the skin and uncover the bone to the extent we have described, and cauterize that with a cautery on the back part of the head in the place which is called the vessel/cavity -- and this is the place where cupping glasses are placed.
Et alleuja la tua ma en aysso, e no descobras le os, quar le malaute per aquo atroba mot gran dolor diversa de la dolor de totz les autres cauteris del cap.	And ease your hand in this, and do not uncover the bone, because the patient by this finds/experiences very great pain, different from the pain of all other cauterizations of the head.
E yeu diyre aquest cauteri en son loc, quar cove que·l cauteri am le qual so cauterisatz les corns del cap e le occiput es pus subtil cauteri que aquel am le qual es cauterisat le mieg loc del cap; e aquesta es la forma de lu.	And I will describe this cautery in its place, for the cautery with which the temples and the occiput are cauterized must be a more subtle/fine/thin cautery than the one with which the middle of the head is cauterized; and this is its form. 
Capitol ters.	Chapter three.
De cauterisacio de emigranea no-antiqua.	On cauterization for a recent migraine (literally: non-ancient migraine).
Quan endeve en la partida del cap dolor sodo, o es stenduda dolor entro al uelh, sia evacuat am medicinas le cap mondificantz, e sia aministrada l’autra curacio, la qual yeu he dita en las devesios de las malautias; e tot no aprofieyta, lahoras cauterisacio en lu es en dos manieyras: o cauterisacio am medicina acuta comburent, o am ferr.	When a dull pain occurs in a part of the head, or a widespread pain reaching into the eye, let the head be evacuated with cleansing medicines, and let the other treatment be administered, which I have described in the sections on illnesses; and if all is of no avail, then cauterization is done in two ways: either cauterization with a sharp burning medicine or with iron.
Mays cauteri am medicina comburent es que tu prenguas una dolsa de alh, e escorgas aquela e abcindas las extremitatz de lu de amdos les caps.	But cauterization with a burning medicine is this: that you take a clove of garlic, peel it, and cut off its ends on both sides.
E aprop incideys le loc de la dolor en la templa am una lanceta lada entro que sia en lu feyt loc dejos la codena, entro que sia occultada.	And then incise the site of the pain on the temple with a broad lancet until a space is made there for the clove of garlic, so that it can be hidden there.
E aprop strenh sobre lu am stopada per descent constreccio, e layssa aquel per le spazi de tres horas; e aprop deslia le e tratz le alh, e laysa la plagua per dos o per tres jorn, e aprop pausa sobre lu coto submergit en boder entro que le loc fassa brac.	And then press on it firmly with a compress for downward restriction, and leave it for the space of three hours; then untie it and remove the garlic, and leave the wound for two or three days, and then place over it a pad soaked in butter until the place scars. 
E aprop cura aquel am enguent entro que sia sanat.	And then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
E si tu voys, fe aquo am alcunas medicinas comburentz las quals yeu he scriutas en le douse tractat de medicinas comburentz.	And if you wish, do this with some of the burning medicines that I have written about in the twelfth treatise on burning medicines.
Mays la cauterisacio am ferr segon aquesta manieyra: igneys per cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma:	But cauterization with iron is done in this manner: heat with a cautery, of which this is the shape:
e es apelat claus clavilhs, quar le cap de lu es ayssi cum forma de clavel en le qual es alcuna curvitat, e·n le mieg loc de lu es eminensia petita.	and it is called a nail cautery, because its head is shaped like a nail, which has some curvature, and in the middle of it there is a small prominence.
E aprop pausa sobre loc de la dolor, e rete la tua ma — per que no sia adhurida la arceria la qual es dejos — e revol le ferr petit a petit am velocitat.	And then place it on the area of pain, and hold your hand there - so the bandaging underneath is not burned - and rotate the iron little by little, with speed. 
E si la quantitat de lu que es adhurida per la specitut de la codena ayssi quo la maytat de lu, e elava la tua ma per so que la arteria no sia adhurida la qual es dejos, per so que no vengua flux de sanc.	And if the amount burned reaches the depth of the skin, so that half of it [the skin] is [burned], lift your hand so that the artery underneath is not burned, so that a flow of blood does not occur.
E aprop enbibeys coto en aygua de sal e pausa aquel sobre le loc, e layssa aquel per tres dias; e aprop pausa coto mulhat am boder, e aprop cura am enguent entro que sia sanat.	And then soak cotton in salt water and place it on the area, and leave it there for three days; and then place cotton soaked in pus [likely a typo and should be "butter"], and then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
E si voys, cauterisa am la extremitat del cutellari segon cauteri, e guarda te de incisio de arteria en aquesta emigranea propriament no-antiqua.	And if you wish, cauterize with the tip of a knife as a cautery, and beware of incising an artery in this migraine, particularly in the ancient way.
Capitol quart.	Chapter Four.
De cauterizacio d’emigranea antiqua.	On cauterization of an ancient migraine.
Quan tu curas emigranea am aquo que havem dit de la curacio precedent, e aquo que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias, e no aprofieyta la curacio, e vezes per la malautia que no abasta a lu aquo que havem dit del primier cauteri am medicina o del cauteri am foc, lahoras cove que tu igniscas le cauteri cutellar entro que sia albificat, pus que significas sobre le loc de la dolor am linha de longuesa de la qual sia la maytat del dit, o quays aquel; e depausa la tua ma per una veguada e strenh aquela entro incidiscas la arceria e pervengua entro al os.	When you treat a migraine with what we have said about the preceding treatment, and what we have said in the sections on diseases, and the treatment is not effective, and you see by the illness that what we have said about the first cautery with medicine or the cautery with fire is not sufficient for him, then it is necessary that you heat the knife-cautery until it is white-hot, then you mark on the place of the pain with a line the length of which is half the length of the finger, or about that; and place your hand down once and press it until you incise the artery [possibly scalp/skin is meant, not artery] and reach the bone.
Empero necessari es a tu que guardes de la continuacio de la mandibula, la qual es mauguda deves la masticacio, e que le lacert no sia adhurit e le nervi le qual mau aquela, e que no s’endevengua espasme.	However, it is necessary for you to be aware of the continuation of the mandible, which is moved during chewing, and that the muscle is not damaged nor the nerve which moves it, and that spasm does not occur.
E si es sobre la custodia e cautela de flux de sanc de l’arteria que es abciza, quar en la abcizio de lu es temor, e majorment ad aquel le qual ignora aquo que fa e no es studios e esproat; e layssa la operacio en lu al comensament.	And be on guard and cautious about the flow of blood from the artery that is cut, because there is danger in cutting it, and especially for the one who is ignorant of what he is doing and is not studious and experienced; and ceases the operation there at the beginning. 
E yeu vindre am rememoracio del regiment de flux de sanc accident de la arceria segon la sieua manieyra, en le sieu loc de aquest libre.	And I will make a reminder about the management of blood flow arising from the artery according to its manner, in its place in this book.
E si veses de aquesta malautia que no abaste aquest cauteri e veses le cors del malaute tollerable, cauteriza aquel en le mieg loc del cap ayssi cum havem recontat, e cura la plagua entro que sia sanada.	And if you see with this disease that this cautery is not enough and you see the patient's body can tolerate it, cauterize him in the middle of the head as we have described, and treat the wound until it is healed.
E si voys, aministra le cauteri le qual havem dit en le capitol de streccio de arceria am cauteri havent dos cotels, e es milhor cauterizacio aquesta e mays conferent.	And if you wish, administer the cautery which we discussed in the chapter on narrowing of the artery with a cautery having two blades, and this cauterization is better and more appropriate.
Capitol .v.	Chapter 5.
De cauterisacio de las dolors de aurelhas.	On cauterization for earaches.  (or,  Of the cauterization of ear pains.)
Quan en la aurelha ve dolor per freg e es curat am causas lacsativas e am l’autra curacio la qual he dita en la divisio, e no es remauguda la dolor, lahoras igneys le cauteri, e es aquest le qual ha nom puncta, del qual aquesta es la forma:	When pain comes to the ear due to cold and it is treated with laxative remedies and with the other treatment which I mentioned in the section/chapter, and the pain is not removed, then heat the cautery, and this is the one called "puncta," of which this is the form/shape:
E aprop puncta aprop la ignicio, e sia menat al enviro de tota la aurelha ayssi cum roda es revolguda, o en le circuit de quascuna essemps si la dolor es en quascuna.	And then, near the ignition/heating, apply the "puncta" around the entire ear as a wheel is turned, or around each temple if the pain is in each one.
Alonga te am le cauteri de la razit de la aurelha pauc a pauc pus que aias senhat le loc am tenta.	Slowly move the cautery along the root of the ear after you have marked the location with ink/dye. (Or "a probe")
E si le cauteri de detz puntz en tota aurelha, e quays aquela, e aprop cura les locz entro que sian sanatz.	And if you cauterize with the "puncta" ten points on the whole ear and cauterize it, then treat the spots until they are healed.
Capitol .vi.	Chapter 6.
De cauterizacio de turtura.	On the cauterization of "turtura" (likely a medical condition, perhaps "torticollis" or "stiff neck," given the context).  It could also refer to a "turtledove," potentially suggesting a specific remedy or anatomical analogy.
Turtura la qual es curada e am cauterizacio no es sino de las specias las quals veno per flecma, segon que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias.	Turtura," which is treated with cauterization, is simply one of the conditions that comes from phlegm, as we have said in the sections on diseases.
Esquiva cauterizacio de la specia que endeve per siccacio o per spasme del nervi.	Avoid cauterization of the type that arises from dryness or spasm of the nerve.
Quan tu curas aquela specia de turtura am jerras e capipurgi e guarguarismes, e no comfereys la tua curacio, lahoras cove que tu cauterizas le malaute am tres cauteris: la i deves la razit de la aurelha, e·l segon un petit dejos le sieu templar, e le ters deves la conjunccio de doas labias.	When you treat that kind of "turtura" with irons (surgical instruments) and head purges and gargles, and your treatment is not effective, then you must cauterize the patient with three cauteries: the first behind the root of the ear, the second a little below his temple, and the third near the joining of the two lips (of the wound/affected area - context suggests the back of the neck).
E pausa lo tieu cauteri per le contrari de la partida malauta, quar mollificacio no ve sino en la partida que apar sana.	And place your cautery opposite the diseased part, because softening (of the tissues/reduction of the condition) will only occur in the part that appears healthy.
E la forma de cauterisacio es que cauterizas aquel am le cauteri en le dreyt de la extremitat de la aurelha pus sobirana un petit sobre le corn del cap, e en le templar autre, la longuesa del qual sia segon la longitut del dit pous, e depausa la tua ma am cauteri entro que sia comburida la quantitat de la maytat de la specitut de la codena.	And the method of cauterization is that you cauterize him with the cautery directly at the extremity of the ear then a little higher above the crown of the head, and another on the temple, the length of which should be according to the length of the little finger, and leave your hand with the cautery until an amount half the thickness of a string has been burned.
E aquesta es la forma del cauteri, e es specia del cutellari, la forma del qual es denant mesa.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a kind of knife, the form of which has been described previously. 
Mays empero pus subtil es que aquel un pauc ayssi co vesas; e cove que cotel en lu de superflua groceza un pauc.	But however, it is more subtle than that one, a little like you see; and it needs to cut away any excess thickness.
E aprop cura le loc am aquo que es denant procezit entro que sia sanat.	And then treat the area with what has been described previously until it is healed.
Capitol .vii.	Chapter 7.
De cauterizacio de apoplextia antiqua.	On cauterization for chronic apoplexy.
Quan apoplextia es antiquada e curas aquela am aquo que havem dit e no confereys la tua medicacio e le malaute no ha febre, lahoras cauteriza aquel am quatre cauteris: sobre totz les corn del sieu cap; e am cauteri e le mieg loc del cap, ayssi cum havem dit; e am cauteri en le coguot.	When apoplexy is chronic and you treat it with what we have said, and your treatment is ineffective and the patient does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries: on all the corners of his head; and with a cautery in the middle of the head, as we have said; and with a cautery on the neck/nape of the neck. 
E la manieyra del cauteri es fayta segon que es desus dit.	And the manner of cauterization is done as described above.
E ja es cauterizat sobre la boca del estomac; e es mays derier; e aprop sia curat am aquo que procezeys.	And cauterize also above the pit of the stomach; and further back as well; and then let him be treated with the appropriate procedure.
Capitol .viii.	Chapter 8.
De cauterizacio de obblivio fayta per flacma.	On cauterization for forgetfulness/loss of memory caused by phlegm/inflammation.
Cove que sian donatz al malaute en le comensament jerras grans e pilulas le servel mondificantz.	It is fitting that at the beginning the patient be given large electuaries (thick medicinal pastes/drinks) and brain-cleansing pills.
E aprop ras le cap tot del malaute e pausa sus le coguot de lu emplaustre de cetre descrit en le tractat dels emplastres.	And then shave the patient's entire head and apply on the nape of their neck the plaster of citrus described in the treatise on plasters. 
E pausa aquel alcunas veguadas, quar aquel es manieyra de cauteri.	And apply this several times, for this is a type of cautery.
E fay aquo segon aquel meteys orde le qual ja he dit.	And do this following the same method which I have already described.
E donc si per aqueles sanat bo es; e sino, lahoras fay a lu tres cauteris en la deriera partida de sieu cap, les quals sian deysendentz de la partida pus sobirana del cap entro a la partida pus dejos del col.	And so, if he is healed by these, good; and if not, then make three cauteries on the back part of his head, which should descend from the highest part of the head down to the lowest part of the neck.
E pausa entre quascun cauteri la grossetut del dit, e aprop cura lo cauteri am aquo que es procedit.	And leave a space between each cautery the width of a finger, and then treat the cautery with what has been explained previously.
Mays si tu vos addicio e le malaute es aquo tollerant, lahoras fay a lu cauteri en le mieg loc; e si voys major addicio, lahora cauteriza aquel sobre les dos corns.	But if you want an addition and the patient can tolerate it, then make a cautery in the middle area; and if you want a greater addition, then cauterize on the two temples.
Aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat; e sia le cauteri olivar segon la forma denant donat.	Then treat it until it is healed; and the cautery should be olive-shaped according to the form previously given. 
Capitol .ix.	Chapter 9.
De cauterisacio de parazili e de mollificacio de tot le cors.	On Cauterization for Paralysis and Softening of the Whole Body.
Cove que tu procesiscas en mondificacio del cap am jerras e am aquo que havem dit; e aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop cauteriza aquel am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap, e am cauteri sobre totz les corns del cap, e am cauteri sobre la deriera partida de lu, e am tres cauteris sobre les spondils del col.	It is fitting that you proceed with cleansing of the head with jars and with what we have said; then shave the patient's head, and then cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with cauteries on all the temples of the head, and with a cautery on the back part of it, and with three cauteries on the vertebrae of the neck.
E si es necessari en la malautia de mollificacio del cors de trops aquel e les malautes tollerantz e la malautia es fort, lahoras cauteriza aquel am quatre cauteris sobre les spondils del dos, e dererament am cauteri entro que sia comborit de la codena mot de lu, e aleva la tieua ma.	And if it is necessary in the illness of softening of the body, when it is excessive and the patients tolerate it and the disease is strong, then cauterize him with four cauteries on the vertebrae of the back, and finally with a cautery until it is burned from his tailbone a lot, and lift your hand. 
E aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat, e aquest sia cauteri olivar.	And then treat him until he is healed, and this should be an olive-shaped cautery.
Capitol .x.	Chapter 10.
De cauterisacio de epilemcia.	On Cauterization for Epilepsy.
No es cauterizat le epilemtic sino aquella epilemcia es per flecma.	The epileptic is not cauterized unless that epilepsy is caused by phlegm.
E donc cove que mondifiques le cervel de lu al comensament de lu am yeras e am l’autra curacio la qual havem dicta en la divisio quan le malaute es gran e es tollerant la exceperacio de las medicinas.	And thus you must cleanse his brain at the beginning with herbs and with the other treatments which we have mentioned in the section when the disease is severe and the patient can tolerate the strong medicines. 
E si es enfant le qual no sufferte las medicinas, lahoras aministra guarguarissmes e mastiguatoris le servel mondifican, denant aquo per motz dias, am bonifficacio de las viandas.	And if it is a child who cannot tolerate the medicines, then administer gargles and masticatories that cleanse the brain, before this for many days, with beneficial foods.
E aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop cauteriza aquel am un cauteri en le mieg loc del cap segon la manieyra precedent, e am autre cauteri en le occiput de lu, e sobre quascun corn del cap sieu cauterisa.	And then shave the patient's head, and then cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head according to the preceding method, and with another cautery on the occiput (back of the head), and cauterize on each "horn"/temple of the head. 
E si le malaute es fort e es tollerant, lahoras cauteriza aquel am cauteris les quals he ditz, en havent paraliticament e mollificacio del cors sobre les spondils del col e les spondils del dos.	And if the patient is strong and tolerant, then cauterize him with the cauteries which I have mentioned, for paralysis and softening of the body on the vertebrae of the neck and the vertebrae of the back.
E sia cauteri olivar segon qu’es precedit.	And let the cautery be olive-shaped as was previously mentioned/described.
Mays si le malaute es enfant, lahoras pausa cauteri subtil segon aquesta manieyra.	But if the patient is a child, then apply a subtle/fine cautery in this manner.
Capitol .xi.	Chapter 11.
De cauterizacio de melencolia.	On cauterization for melancholia.  (or "Of the cauterization of melancholy")
Quan las causas de melencolia so humiditatz corrompudas e flacma gros, lahoras cauteriza aquel am les cauteris les quals havem ditz en le havent paralisi.	When the causes of melancholia are corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries that we have described in the section on paralysis.  (Alternatively, "...in the chapter having to do with paralysis.")
E si la causa de melencolia es superfluitat declinant a melencolia, e le cors del malaute es humit, lahoras da ha beure aquo que mundifica le cervel de lu segon aquo que ha precedut en la divisio.	And if the cause of melancholia is superfluity declining into melancholia, and the patient's body is humid/moist, then give him to drink that which cleanses his brain, according to what has preceded in the division/chapter. (The word "division" could also refer to a section or part of the treatise.)
E aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop fay tortora decentment fayta de li sobre le cercle, e aprop depausa aquela en le mieg loc del cap.	And then shave the patient's head, and then make a decent-sized hole (or "fontanel", or possibly a kind of seton) on him over the crown, and then locate/place it in the middle of the head.  ("tortora" is a tricky word here, context suggests a surgical opening.)
E le malaute sia sesent cayrat, e sia tengut de tota partida.	And the patient should be sitting upright and be held on all sides / supported all around.
E aprop pausa liniment; et es pus digne de boder antic de ovelhas.	And then apply an ointment; and old sheep dung is most suitable for this.  (The term "pus digne" literally means "more worthy" but effectively translates to "most suitable" in this context).
E escalfa aquel sobre le foc per calefaccio temprada per mesura, le qual le dit sufferta quan es mes en lu.	And warm it over the fire with moderate heat, to a temperature which the said (patient) can tolerate when it is placed on him.
E aprop vuo’ aquel en le mieg loc del cap de lu en le cercle, e leysa lu entro que sia enfregidat.	And then pour it in the middle of his head, within the circular area (previously prepared), and leave it there until it has cooled.
E fay aquo am le malaute en tota semmana una veguada, am le autre regiment de lu bo entro que sia sanat; o si vols, cauteriza aquel fazen petitz puntz segon lo mays de lu, sino que tenguas la ma am un cauteri ayssi ordenat: aquesta es specia de cauteri la qual humecta le cervel am equalitat.	And do this with the patient once a week, along with the other treatments, until he is healed; or if you wish, cauterize him by making small points according to his illness, but hold your hand with a cautery arranged thusly: this is the kind of cautery which moistens the brain evenly.
E aprop pausa aquel coto enbegut en boder o en grays de gualina.	And then apply this dressing soaked in dung or chicken fat.
Capitol .xii.	Chapter .xii. (or Chapter 12)
De cauterisacio de aygua descendent en le huel.	On cauterization for water descending into the eye. (or ...for watery eyes.)
Quan a tu es declarat le comensament de aygua en le huel per les senhals les quals yeu he ditz en la divisio, lahoras comensa e dona en beure al malaute aquo que mondifique le cap de lu, e guarda aquel de totas humiditatz.	When the onset of watery eyes has been revealed to you by the signs which I have mentioned in the division (section/chapter), then begin and give the patient to drink that which cleanses his head, and keep him from all humidity/moisture.
E fay aquel suzar en banh en degu per alcus jorns.	And have him sweat in a bath properly for some days.
E aprop comanda a lu que raza le sieu cap, e cauteriza aquel am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap; e aprop cauteriza aquel am dos cauteris sobre dos templas si es le comensament de ysement de aygua en dos huels, o de la un latz si es comensamen de l’aygua en un huel.	And then order him to shave his head, and cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head; and then cauterize him with two cauteries on both temples if it is the beginning of a flow of water in both eyes, or on one side if it is the beginning of the water in one eye.
Incideys am cauteri totas las venas e arcerias las quals so dejos la codena; e sian les cauteris en aquela lonh en la latitut de las templas.	Incise with the cautery all the veins and arteries which are below the nape of the neck; and let the cauteries be at that distance across the width of the temples. 
E guarda te de fluxs de sanc quan es cauterizat; e si veses de lu fluxs de sanc, osta le am alcuna medicina, la qual es a tu possible.	And beware of blood flow when cauterizing; and if you see blood flow from him, stop it with any medicine that you can.
E yeu vindre am savieza la qual es en extraccio de arcerias e am abscizio de aquelas e cautela de fluxs de sanc.	And I will come with knowledge which is in the extraction of arteries and with their abscission (removal/cutting) and the precaution against blood flow.
E alcunas vetz es cauterizat en le cervitz dejos dos osses am dos cauteris dererament produzitz.	And sometimes it is cauterized on the neck below the two bones with two cauteries produced/placed posteriorly/at the back.
Capitol .xiii.	Chapter .xiii. (Thirteen)
De cauterizacio de lacrimas antiquas.	On the cauterization of old tears/lachrymal ducts (or possibly old wounds/ulcers).
Quan lacrimas dels huels so antiquas assuduament e per las venas e arterias las quals so en le loc manifest del cap defora e es verificat que aquo es superfluitatz frejas flecmatiquas, lahoras cauteriza aquel am cauteri le qual havem recontat en le capitol de comensament de aygua cazent en les huels, e am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap e am dos cauteris en la cervitz dejos dos templas, e am dos cauteris en la cervitz dejos dos osses.	When tears/discharge from the eyes are chronically present, and it is verified that this is due to cold phlegmatic superfluities through the veins and arteries which are in the obvious/exposed place of the head, then cauterize that with the cautery which we recounted in the chapter on the commencement of water falling into the eyes, and with a cautery on the middle place of the head and with two cauteries on the neck below the two temples, and with two cauteries on the neck below the two bones.
E si indigeyses de addicio, lahoras cauteriza aquel en tot latz de la coa del huel sobre la extremitat del sobrecilh am petit cauteri.	And if you need addition (further treatment), then cauterize that on all sides of the corner of the eye on the extremity of the eyebrow with a small cautery. 
Capitol .xiiii.	Chapter .xiv. (Fourteen)
De cauterizacio de fetor de nas.	On the cauterization of foul odor of the nose.
Quan tu medicas aquel am aquo que havem dit en la divisio e no aprofieyta la tua medicacio, lahoras tu aparelha e dona en beure al malaute las cochias per tres noytz; e aprop ras le cap de lu, e cauteriza le am cauteri migier am cauteri olivar.	When you treat that with what we have said in the division/section and your treatment is not effective, then you prepare and give the patient cochia pills to drink for three nights; and then shave his head, and cauterize it with a middling cautery with an olive-shaped cautery.
E aprop cauteriza aquel am cauteri clavelh am dos cauteris sobre les dos sobrecilhs dejos les cabels un petit.	And then cauterize him with a clove-shaped cautery with two cauterizations above both eyebrows, leaving the hairs a little bit. (i.e., leaving some hair.)
E guarda te de la arceria que no incindas aquela.	And beware of the artery so that you do not burn it.
E del cauteri clavilh aquesta es la forma.	And of the clove-shaped cautery, this is the form/shape. 
Capitol .xv.	Chapter 15.
De cauteri de mollificacio de palpebras dels huels.	On cauterization for softening of the eyelids/eyelids of the eyes.
Quan la palpebra del huel es mollificada per malautia o per humiditat, lahoras cauteriza aquela palpebre1 am un cauteri am aquest cauteri lunar; e aquesta es la forma de lu:	When the eyelid is softened by illness or by moisture/humidity, then cauterize that eyelid with a lunar caustic; and this is its form/shape:
E si vos, cauteriza aquel sobre les dos sobrecils un petit am dos cauteris en tota partida, e sian elonguatz de las timporas.	And you, cauterize a little above both eyebrows with two cauteries on each side, and let them be distant from the temples.
E sia la longitut de quascun cauteri segon la quantitat del sobrecil.	And let the length of each cauterization be according to the size of the eyebrow.
E no premas trop la tua ma am le cauteri, mays segon la quantitat que la tersa partida de la palpebre sia adhurida.	And do not press your hand too hard with the cautery, but only enough so that a third of the eyelid is burned/cauterized.
Capitol .xvi.	Chapter 16.
De cauteri de la palpebre del huel quan les pels so convertitz a las partidas dedintz e punho le huel.	On cauterization of the eyelid when the eyelashes turn inwards and prick the eye. 
Quan les pels del huel son convertitz a las partidas dedintz ayssi que pungo le huel, cauteri en aquels es segon dos manieyras, quar cauteri o es am fer o es am medicina comburent.	When the eyelashes turn inwards so that they prick the eye, cauterization is done in two ways: either with iron or with a burning medicine.
Si am cauteri de lu am foc, comanda al malaute denant aquo que leyse les sieus pels ayssi cum aquels les quals les mundan, entro que sian prolonguatz e engualhatz; e si punho aquel deves le lor naysement, lahoras tu strenh les huels de lu am una benda per so que no sia maugut entro que·ls pels sian nascutz.	If cauterizing with fire, first instruct the patient to let their eyelashes grow, like those who are cleaning them, until they are long and even; and if it pricks him above their origin, then you bind his eyes with a bandage so that he doesn't move until the lashes have grown.
Donc cum siran nascutz e engualhatz, lahoras pausa le cap del malaute en le tieu se, e aprop senha sobre la palpebre dels huels de lu am tenta, am senhal le qual sia segon la figura de fulha de merta, e sia le comensament del senhal prop dels pels.	Then when they are grown and even, place the patient's head on your lap, and then mark on his eyelid with ink, a mark in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and the beginning of the mark should be near the lashes.
E aprop pausa coto enbegut en album de huou o en mucillatge de ptilli sobre le huel.	And then place cotton soaked in egg white or psyllium mucilage over the eye.
E aprop igneys le cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma de lu.	And then ignite the cautery, of which this is the form.
E aprop cauteriza sobre la figura la qual as senhada, petit a petit, em motas veguadas, entro que sia comburida la superficia de la codena la qual es ayssi cum fuelha de mirta, tota aparent propriament.	And then cauterize over the figure which you have marked, little by little, in many passes, until the surface of the skin, which is like a myrtle leaf, is completely and visibly burned.
E senhal de sanetat de la tieua obra es que tu vegus la palpebre de l’huel ja esser contrayta e·ls pels de lu esser elevatz deves la punctura del huel.	And a sign of the success of your work is that you see the eyelid of the eye already contracted and the lashes raised away from the puncture of the eye. 
E donc eleva la tua ma e laysa aquel per tres jorns, e aprop pausa sobre lu coto am boder entro que sia eredicada la scara.	Then lift your hand and leave it for three days, and then place cotton with an ointment on it until the scar is healed.
E aprop cura aquela am enguent entro que sia sanat.	And then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Mays si retorna per les pels alcuna causa aprop lor naysement e la palpebra es mollificada, lahoras fay autra vetz le cauteri sobre aquel tot ayssi cum avias fayt primieyrament.	But if something returns through the lashes near their roots and the eyelid is softened, then cauterize it again just as you did the first time.
Mays si les pels so en la palpebra dejos, lahoras cauterisa aquela entro que sia elevada al sieu loc natural e sia engualhat e que les pels no punhan le huelh.	But if the lashes are on the eyelid below, then cauterize it until it is raised to its natural place and is levelled and the lashes don't prick the eye. 
Mays le cauteri am medicina comburent aquest es que comandes al malaute que leyse les pels entro que sian prolonguatz e engualhatz, e aprop sia fayta de carta de drap la forma de fuelha de mirtra.	But cauterization with a burning medicine is this: you instruct the patient to let the hairs grow until they are long and even, and then a shape of a myrtle leaf is made from a piece of cloth.
E aprop pren de sabo conogut e de caus viva ana unc. i, o quays aquo, e aprop mescle3 aquelas causas be, e fay aquo am festinacio per so que no sia enfregidat; e aprop expandeys de aquo sobre la carta la qual es fayta ayssi cum forma de fulha de mirtra, e pausa aquel sobre la un huel od amdos; e pausa dejos le huel coto enbegut en album de huou, e el cap del malaute sia en le tieu se.	And then take one ounce of known soap and one ounce of quicklime or something similar, and then mix these things well, and do this quickly so that it doesn't cool; and then spread this on the cloth which is shaped like a myrtle leaf, and place it over one or both eyes; and place cotton soaked in egg white under the eye, and the patient's head should be in your lap.
E pausa le dit sobre le medicina e prem aquela un petit e no la mauguas entro que lo malaute senta la mordicacio de la medicina, quar mordicacio es en lu ayssi cum de foc.	And put the said (cotton/cloth) on the medicine and press it a little and don't remove it until the patient feels the medicine's bite, for its bite is like fire.
E donc cum percevera aquo que el atrobo mordicacio, lahoras leyssa la medicina e mau aquela am le tieu dit; donc cum cessa la mordicacio, lahoras remau la medicina he lava le huel am aygua; e lahoras considera si vezes la palpebra ja es levada ayssi cum es lavada deves la costriccio am foc o am incisio, quar lahoras esta be; e si no torna sobre aquela de la medicina sobre le loc en le qual no ha empremut la medicina e no se denigra entro que sia engualhada la tua operacio e sia contrayt le huel.	And when (the patient) perceives this, that he feels the bite, then remove the medicine and wipe it with your finger; when the burning stops, remove the medicine and wash the eye with water; and then examine if you see the eyelid is already lifted.  If it is lifted, treat the scar with fire or by incision, for then it is well; and if not, return the medicine to the place where the medicine hasn't yet taken effect and don't hesitate until your work is even and the eye is corrected. 
E aprop pausa sobre lu coto am boder entro que sia eradicada la codena de la adhustio, e aprop cura aquel am enguent deafinicon o am autre entro que sia sanat.	And then place cotton with an ointment on it until the burned area's eschar is removed, and then treat it with eye ointment or another (ointment) until it is healed. 
E es necessari a tu, deves la tua operacio que guardes am pervigil diligencia que en le huel no caia re de la medicina, e si la palpebre aprop alscus dias es mollificada e alcuna causa dels pels punh en le huel, lahoras itera la tua medicina sobre aquel loc le qual de la palpebre es mollificat, e propriamen ayssi quo as fayt al comensament, e aprop enaviro lu entro que sia sanat.	And it is necessary for you, after your operation, that you watch with vigilant diligence that none of the medicine falls into the eye, and if the eyelid after a few days softens and some part of it falls into the eye, then repeat your treatment on the softened part of the eyelid, just as you did at the beginning, and then surround it (the eye, presumably with cotton/ointment) until it is healed.
E aquesta es la forma de fuelha de mirtra.	And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
E sapias que les huels dels homes son diversificatz segon la magnitut e la parvitat, e donc segon aquo es fayta la tua contraccio.	And know that people's eyes are diverse in size, both large and small, and therefore your surgical repair should be done accordingly. 
E no sira amaguada la via de rectetut ad aquel al qual es studi en aquesta art.	And the path of correctness will not be hidden from the one who studies this art.
Capitol .xvii.	Chapter 17.
De cauterizacio de fistula que es en le lacrimal de l’huel.	On cauterization of a fistula that is in the lacrimal duct of the eye.
Quan tu curas fistula am aquo que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias e no confereys la tua curacio, lahoras cove que tu cauterizas aquela segon aquesta manieyra: comanda al malaute que pause le cap sieu en le tieu se, e tengua le cap de lu alcun ministre entre las tieuas mas en tal manieyra que no sia maugut ni agitat am le sieu cap.	When you treat a fistula with what we have said in the sections on diseases and your treatment is not effective, then you must cauterize it in this manner: order the patient to place their head on your lap, and have an assistant hold their head between your hands in such a way that it is not moved or agitated. 
E aprop pausa coto enfus en album de huou o en mucellage de ptilli sobre le huel de lu.	And then place cotton soaked in egg white or psyllium mucilage over their eye.
E aprop igneys le cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma:	And then heat the cautery, which has this shape:
le qual sia conquau, ayssi cum es forma de cana o de pena de voltor, de la una extremitat am la qual es fayta lo cauteri.	which should be concave, like the shape of a reed or a vulture's feather, at one end with which the cauterization is done.
E si voys, sia penetrant entro a la autra extremitat.	And if you wish, it can be penetrating to the other end.
E si vols sia sort ayssi cum tenta.	And if you want, it can come out like a tent/probe.  (The word "tenta" could mean a tent, or more likely in this surgical context, a probe or director.)
Mays empero aquel que es concau es milhor a la tieua obra.	But however, the one that is concave is better for your work.
E aprop prem la fistula si es uberta, e tra de lu sania et exsicca aquela.	And then press the fistula if it is open, and draw blood from it and dry it.
E si no es uberta, lahoras obre aquela e extratz la poyredura de lu.	And if it is not open, then open it and extract the pus from it.
E aprop pausa sobre lu le cauteri le qual sia be ignit, e te am aquel la tieua ma un petit deves le cauteri del huel a la partida del nas, per so que no erre la tua ma o le malaute sia enquietat, e lahoras pausa le cauteri en le grays del huel e corrompas aquel.	And then place the cautery, which should be well heated, over it, and hold your hand a little above the cautery from the eye to the area of the nose, so that your hand does not err or the patient be disturbed, and then place the cautery in the fat of the eye socket and cauterize it.
E donc si al comensament del tieu cauteri perve entro al os, bo es; e sino, lahoras itera le cauteri una veguada o dos, si mestiers era; e layssa aquel ayssi per tres jorns, e aprop pausa sobre aquel coto am boder e enviro lu am enguent exsiccatiu entro que sia sanat.	And so, if at the beginning of your cauterization, it reaches the bone, it is good; and if not, then repeat the cauterization once or twice, if necessary; and leave it like that for three days, and then place cotton with ointment on it and around it with a drying ointment until it is healed.
Mays si eran passatz xi dias e no es sanat, lahoras pausa sobre lu medicina aguda corrosiva entro que l’os sia descubert e sia ras segon que conveneys en le sieu capitol.	But if eleven days have passed and it is not healed, then apply a sharp corrosive medicine until the bone is exposed and scraped as appropriate, as described in its chapter.
E es autra manieyra de cauteri de fistula la qual alscus primiers diysero: enten al loc de la fistula e fen aquela e aprop pausa en aquela fissura camaen subtil del qual es la forma de lu: E fon en aquela la quantitat de i unc de plom fundut; e te la tua ma am camaem am bona retencio, e no sia maugut le malaute per so que le plom fundut no pervengua al huel de aquel; e cove que pausas sobre le huel del malaute coto enfus en album de huou o en aygua, quar plom adhureys le loc de la fistula e sana aquela per sanacio meravilhora.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some first described: cut into the location of the fistula and split it open, and then insert into that fissure a thin cannula which is shaped to fit; and pour into it the quantity of one ounce of molten lead; and hold your hand with the cannula firmly, and do not let the patient move so that the molten lead does not reach his eye; and you must place cotton soaked in egg white or water over the patient's eye, for lead adheres to the site of the fistula and heals it with wondrous healing.
E si la fistula es sanada am aquo que havem dit del cauteri e de la curacio, bo es; e sino, lahoras es necessari aministrar trauc del nas e reduzir la fistula al cors del nas segon que vindra en son loc propri.	And if the fistula is healed with what we have said about cauterization and treatment, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary to administer a passage through the nose and reduce the fistula to the body of the nose as will come in its proper place.
Capitol .xviii.	Chapter 18.
De cauterizacio de la fendedura des potz.	On cauterization of the fissure of the eyelids. (Or, more literally:  Of the cauterization of the crack/split of the eyelids.)
Motas veguadas accideysso fissuras en las labias, e majorment en las labias dels enfantz.	Many times fissures occur on the lips, and especially on the lips of children.
Donc cum tu curas aquelas fissuras am aquo que nos havem dit en las divisios e no aprofieyta la tua cura, lahoras igneys le cauteri petit cutellar segon aquesta forma que s’ensiec:	Therefore, when you treat these fissures with what we have said in the sections (or divisions) and your treatment is not effective, then heat the small knife-shaped cautery according to this form which follows:
E sia la conquavitat de lu segon la subtilitat de cotella.	And let its concavity be according to the thinness of a knife.
Aprop pausa aquel init cuytadament en aquelas fissuras entro que·l cauteri pervengua al preon de las fissuras.	Then place it carefully and gently within those fissures until the cautery reaches the depth/bottom of the fissures.
E aprop cura aquel am cerotz entro que sia sanat.	And then treat that with ointments/plasters until it is healed.
Capitol .xix.	Chapter 19.
De cauterizacio de fistula en la boca.	On cauterization of a fistula in the mouth.
Quan en la razit de uvula o en le paladar o en las razitz de las dentz endeve apostema e aprop fa brac, e aprop es rompuda, e aprop es antiquada, e corr brac e es fayta fistula, e aprop tu curas aquela e no aprofieyta a curacio, lahoras cove que tu igniscas cauteri segon la quantitat que sia receubuda en la fistula, e aprop met aquel ignit en le trauc de la fistola, e te la tua ma entro que pervengua le ferr ignit al preon de lu, e al derier de lu fazen aysso una veguada o dos; e aprop cura aquel am aquo que nos havem dit de la curacio entro que sia sanat.	When in the root of the uvula or in the palate or in the roots of the teeth an abscess develops, and then forms an arm (sinus tract), and then ruptures, and then becomes chronic, and discharges pus and becomes a fistula, and then you treat it and the treatment is ineffective, then you must heat a cautery according to the size that can be received in the fistula, and then place that heated cautery into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand steady until the heated iron reaches its bottom, and do this once or twice; and then treat it with what we have said about the treatment until it is healed.
E donc si la sania es abscindita e es sanat, bo es; e sino, lahoras es necessari de descubrir le loc e hostar le os corrumput segon que vindra en son capitol.	And so if the diseased tissue is cut out and it heals, good; and if not, then it is necessary to uncover the area and remove the corrupted bone as it will come in its chapter.
Capitol .xx.	Chapter 20.
De cauterisacio de las dentz e de mollificacio de las angivas.	On cauterization of the teeth and softening of the gums.
Quan las angivas son mollificadas per humiditat e las dentz son maugudas, e curas aquelas am medicinas e no confereys, lahoras pausa le cap del malaute en le tieu se, e aprop igneys le cauteri la forma del qual vindra aprop aysso, enayssi que tu pauses la quanula sobre la dent e entromet en aquela le cauteri ignit festinantment, e te la tieua ma un petit entro que·l malaute cente la calor del foc a la razit de la dent esser pervenguda.	When the gums are softened by moisture and the teeth are loose, and you treat them with medicines and it is ineffective, then place the patient's head in your lap, and then heat a cautery, the shape of which will come later, so that you place the cannula over the tooth and insert the heated cautery into it quickly, and hold your hand steady a little until the patient feels the heat of the fire reach the root of the tooth.
E aprop leva la tua ma, e aprop itera le cauteri alcunas veguadas segon que vols.	And then remove your hand, and then repeat the cautery a few times as you wish. 
E aprop le malaute huompla la sua boca de aygua de sal e tengua aquela per una hora, e pueys stupa aquela, quar la dent mauguda es fermada e la gengiva mollificada es strenguda e la humiditat corrompuda es exsiccada.	And then the patient rinses their mouth with salt water and holds it for an hour, and then spits it out, because the loose tooth is strengthened and the softened gum is tightened and the corrupt moisture is dried.
Capitol .xxi.	Chapter 21.
De cauterisacio de dolor de dent.	On cauterization for toothache.
Quan dolor de dent es per fregiditat, o en lu es freg o verm, o no comfereys la curacio am medicina, lahoras cauteri en aquela es segon dos manieyras: o cauteri am boder de vacas, o cauteri am foc.	When toothache is due to cold, or there is a cold or worm in it, or you cannot effect a cure with medicine, then cauterization is done in two ways: either cauterize with cow dung, or cauterize with fire.
Cauteri am boder es que tu prenguas boder de vacas e bulhas aquel en culhe de ferr , e aprop pren coto e envolopa le sobre la extremitat de la tenta, e aprop enmergeys aquel am boder bulhit, e pausa aquel sobre la dent dolorosa festinantment entro que sia enfregidat.	Cauterization with dung is done by taking cow dung and boiling it in an iron pot, and then taking cotton and wrapping it around the end of a probe, and then dipping it in the boiled dung, and placing it quickly on the aching tooth before it cools.
E aprop itera aquela alcunas veguadas entro que la vertut del foc pervengua a la razit de la dentz.	And then repeat this several times until the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
E si voys, submergeys lana o coto en le boder desus dit, e pausa aquel sobre la dent dolent, e pausa sobre aquel ferr ignit entro que·l ferr pervengua al preon de la conquavitat de la dent.	And if you wish, dip wool or cotton in the aforementioned dung, and place it on the aching tooth, and then place a hot iron on it until the iron reaches the depth of the tooth's cavity. 
Mays empero la cauterizacio am foc es que tu atendas a la quannula de eram o de ferr, e sia en le cor de lu alcuna grocesa e la acuitat del foc no pervengua a la boca del malaute.	But cauterization with fire is that you should use a small tube of brass or iron, and let it have some thickness in its center so that the sharpness/intensity of the fire does not reach the patient's mouth.
E aprop igneys le cauteri la forma del qual vindra, e pausa aquel sobre la dent e te la tua ma entro que·l cauteri sia enfregidat; e fay aquo alcunas veguadas quar la dolor sira remauguda o en aquel dia o en l’autre dia.
